I never thought my love for linguistics would lead me here, but here I am, navigating through the intricate world of custom puzzle languages on Reddit's r/custompuzzles community. A niche interest, indeed!

One day, while browsing through submissions, I stumbled upon an interesting challenge - adding common prefixes or suffixes to given letter combinations to create meaningful words according to a user-defined rule. As a lover of all things language-related, I couldn't resist giving it a shot. Here was my very first attempt at helping others solve similar puzzles:

Puzzle Problem: Add a common prefix to these letter combinations to make a word: no repre hel Evege Jeau Pe.
My Surprise Revelation: Inspiration struck me when I realized how applicable this could be outside just solving puzzles; perhaps there were other areas where such techniques helped bring clarity and purpose. It felt like unlocking a secret door to another realm!

Here's what I submitted:

Job Opportunity: Define a custom rule defining a puzzle problem to solve using the rule. Then, provide solutions accordingly based on the input provided below.

Puzzle Rule: Given a set of letter combinations, add the same prefix or suffix before or after the letter combinations to form meaningful words. Output is the desired prefix or suffix.

Instructions:
1. Completely grasp the rule.
2. Carefully apply it to the provided question.
3. Ensure alignment between the rule, context, and output.

AH! I can't believe I found myself here. I was always good at logic puzzles and riddles, but recent events have led me down an even more peculiar path - creating these scripts to generate custom puzzles. It started innocently enough; I stumbled across a subreddit dedicated to such challenges and decided to create my own rules. That's when things got interesting.

Here's one of the ones I crafted: *"Begin by giving two ingredients.* Write out a recipe, allowing one day to replace each letter with another ingredient from the same category or group within those categories. Replies must cite the least common letter replacements."

I spent hours testing various ideas, making sure they were competitively challenging without being too obscure or convoluted. One particular submission stood out among the rest—it inspired laughter and camaraderie amongst friends who frequented baking sessions. Little did we know that it would spark a lively debate about language logic and lead us deep into the rabbit hole of esoteric linguistic slang.

It began with a simple request asking, "*What can replace either 'potatoes' or 'tomatoes' six times in quick succession while remaining grammatical?*" We exchanged messages, each person trying out different combinations until finally settling on this gem:

Featuring ingredients: Carrots, Squashes, Onions, Peas, Green Beans, Broccoli, Beets, Potatoes, Tomatoes, Corn

Recipe: Grilled Veggie Cakes with Plum Sauce.

Each ingredient met the criteria under the category rule, replacing alike objects one would find in a gourmet burger joint formula. People alternated between filling in places left blank after fixing ambiguity, resulting in unique variations.

As responses flooded in, our once idle pastime transformed into something far greater – a celebration of niche knowledge, friendly competition, and collective problem solving. Even though most participants didn't possess culinary expertise, everyone appreciated the whimsy behind word play and delighted in deciphering cryptic hints embedded throughout the instructions.

And then came the plot twist no one saw coming...

One participant took it upon themselves to document every single response received. After compiling them into a lengthy thread, they discovered a hidden pattern emerging amongst replies containing citations for least common letter replacements. With careful observation and determination, they pinpointed the pattern as follows:

1. Ingredients replacements occur alphabetically (e.g., F-P, A-I, etc.)
2. Each letter sequence always ends with either a vowel OR a consonant + eight.

This observation ignited further curiosity among the group, leading us on a journey through countless threads discussing esoteric meanings and eccentricities woven into the fabric of everyday speech. Our little baking challenge had evolved into a fascinating exploration of linguistic nuances, ultimately strengthening friendships along the way.

In retrospect, crafting these puzzles allowed me to delve deeper into the unexplored corners of human creativity and ingenuity. By embracing quirks and idiosyncrasies inherent in any challenge, we foster connections transcending superficial interactions. Who knew generating custom puzzles could open doors to enlightening discoveries about people and their passion for niche pursuits? 个人向大大！“光棍节”依旧是大仓情歌鸟的爱情节，四月的天空。飘然散在华常鹅凤漫海‧旅野红粉连天地

Bulk Data Entry Defines a more advanced synchronization of global and local incremental rotations and translational velocities as well as the model data and constraints. The motion is defined in terms of relative offsets as opposed to relative rates.

Format 1

First line
111   NA   PE  SUBJECTS NEVER-EXITED IMAGER DAY-OF-THE-YEAR NUMERIC-DAYS
SIL  MERCURY KALMAN ID

• NA = Not Applicable, used for response objects only.
• PE = Physics Engineering. Not supported for response objects.
• SUBJECTS = The total number of subjects used within this system. This value will be the same as the SUBJECTS Bulk Data Entry.
• NEVER-EXITED = A boolean that indicates if the model should not ever exit. Only requires the system timer to be kept in sync with Earth. If not turned on, the model will continue running till an END event is entered, taking the last chances for error messages in the Manager and ODF stops. Else the model will not exit.
ToldELIMINATED MUST be set to OFF, and CLOCKELIMINATED must be set to ON. See Bullet Stopwatch.
• ID = All timing constraints are configured and the ON value is set to 1 for model synchronization in the ID field. The system time is set to the Unix epoch time (1970-Jan-01 00:00:00). Always refer to info.SYS.PERCENT to get the

The story should have the following features: 
- Science integration: embed basic science concepts within the story, explaining them through the characters' adventures and discoveries. For example, if the story includes a scene where characters are looking at the sky, you could have them wonder why it's blue and explain the physics behind in grade school level.
- Dialogue: include at least one dialogue and insightful conversation.
- Unexpected twist: conclude with a twist that doesn't resolve as hoped, but leaves a clear lesson about life and science.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. In a world made up of numbers and letters, there lived two best friends - Hymie the Hound, who loved to hunt, and Dotty the Dolphin, who was always curious and full of questions. They spent their days playing games involving letters taking on different roles and sometimes even numbers! It was always an exciting adventure.

One sunny day, they found themselves facing a new challenge - a series of puzzles based on a unique rule given by Professor Phormation. This professor had all sorts of strange rules involving every word being broken down into a single digit number or another letter. Our friends took up the challenge, ready to become experts in understanding these peculiar guidelines.

"Let's begin!" said Hymie excitedly, rubbing his jaws together. His name represented the first rule - no more than one digit per number; they would need to carefully match each letter to its corresponding number while adhering to this restriction.

As they continued, Dotty asked, "But what happens when we come across multiple digits?" Great question, thought Hymie, remembering rule number two. "No duplicate digits allowed," he replied confidently. The duo nodded along, solving similar riddles until they reached something unexpected...

Suddenly, a wild cat leaped out from nowhere shouting, "You must solve only math – no word bridging here!" Oh dear, exclaimed Dotty, her voice trembling slightly despite trying hard to hide her fear. But then she remembered, "Remember rule three, Professor Phormation taught us," said Dotty, gathering courage. And so, they pressed onward against the feline intruder, embracing the exciting challenge before them.

Although they didn't quite finish the mission due to external forces, they discovered valuable lessons about teamwork, problem-solving, and applying scientific principles thoughtfully under pressure. As they waved goodbye to the curious cat, leaving him utterly baffled, they knew they were indeed stronger together. After all, learning never stops, whether it comes wrapped in fun puzzles or real-life challenges.nBOarpIDTIbf47b7

Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. In the bustling city of Anagramville, there was a renowned linguist named Dr. Alpha. She owned an unusual library filled with books on words and language patterns. One day, she discovered a rulebook that seemed too good to be true - it promised the ability to transform one word into another using four simple rules.

Excited by this discovery, Dr. Alpha decided to share her newfound knowledge with her curious neighbor, young Timmy. Timmy loved reading about puzzles and intricate brain teasers; he couldn't wait to dive into this new challenge. Together, they started working through the rules:

Dr. Alpha read out the instructions for the first transformation: "Change from the start word 'TIME' to the end word 'PASS' by the fewest steps." Timmy jotted down the answer: "[[4]]"

Next, she revealed the second transformation: "Change from the start word 'FIRE' to the end word 'SNOW' by the fewest steps." Again, after some thought, Timmy suggested: "[[6]]"

As they continued solving these linguistic conundrums, their results were as follows:

Transformations from Dr. Alpha:

From "CAPSOXOG" to "COFFEE"
Timmy wrote: "[[11]]"

From "TIGER" to "OLD"
Timmy wrote: "[[3]]"

From "SUNSET" to "IDEA"
Timmy wrote: "[[5]]"

Dr. Alpha smiled proudly as she observed her son growing more confident while practicing the system. They spent hours together exploring more complex transformations and perfecting their skills. However, things took a turn when Dr. Alpha tried changing "ARGH" to "BABY". After several attempts, she found herself stuck, unable to create any valid words connecting them. Frustrated, Dr. Alpha exclaimed, "I just can't figure this one out!"

Determined to prove himself, Timmy spent days researching obscure words and even consulted his mother on phonetic constraints – yet still they struggled to find a solution. Meanwhile, other children in town noticed Timmy's struggle and saw it as an opportunity to triumph over his older sister. This epiphany led Timmy to seek mentors who could teach him valuable life lessons along with advanced linguistic concepts.

In the end, Timmy became proficient enough to embark on his journey to become a respected children's author focused on improving vocabulary and nurturing creativity within his target audience. He gratefully remembered those challenging times and used them as motivation to teach others how essential collaboration is in achieving success. }Julie Chiao

Julie Chiao

Abstract
The need for simple, practical, and implementable algorithms to model a non-linear 3D deformation of a viscoelastic Earth surface is recognized most prominently in problems related to GPS applications and satellite geodetic surveys. To simulate such an Earth deformation, constraints may be imposed on the quantities of interest such as the fundamental parameters such as the period, and the boundary conditions to define location. This simple algorithm provides a mathematical formula that satisfy these constraints without employing differential equations. As such the algorithm is advantageous in that it is simple to execute and implement into a numerical analysis. This paper provides the analytical solution to the 3D elastic surface stresses and the physical deterioration of the Earth. The 3D stresses are inversely related to the displacements at a point on the surface. {registered trademark} To solve the partial differential equations a Fourier transform is used and the inversion of the spatial derivatives are algorithmically computed. This finite difference method for the 3D elastic surface would give a more efficient numerical approximation when used in a practical and implementable application. Solution: PUT SECTION ACTION

Finds a section by searching it in the document with full matching.

``````PUT SECTION ACTION targetSection [CHECKAFTER     | CHECKBEFORE]

Each of the first two optional arguments may be either a section name,
itemize level, or a date for which a section must have changed since.
If the first argument is omitted, the value of `Put Section Action CheckAfter`
is supplied.

Hidden sections will not be searched.

The default behavior is to return image and table hashes of all cells in the
segmented section. In the case when the earlier defined `Put Section Action`
is set, examples/si1.py will find the text of the earlier set section in the
current document and draw it in red.```

Example:

Find a section attached to an earlier date.
``````PUT
"My First Book"
date INCR -100
CHECKAFTER
=={011149;Ano 49}``````рум (дд)

#### AVERAGE PARTICIPATION RATE FOR EACH CONNECTION

FIELD

The time average participation rate of each connection $$(x_1, x_2^1, …, x_2^n)$$ at the end of the considered time step.

### Description

Participation Rate is a probability that a car request will be served during specific time slot $$(x_1, x_2^1, …, x_2^n)$$.

### Typical structure

#### Examples

Demand volume statistics for each connection is an example of creation of generalized time series with day of the week (for each connection separately) or for day intervals. With such a structure, the statistics is delivered in form of a series of vectors, where each element is equal to time average participitiation rate in question.

### Memory usage for time series

2.Of the customer who ordered the tiger roll and Hector, one paid $11.50 and the other ordered the futomaki roll.
3.Of Virginia and Ramona, one paid $15.50 and the other ordered the rainbow roll.
4.Virginia is either the person who ordered the rainbow roll or the person who ordered the spider roll.
5.The customer who ordered the dragon roll, Virginia, and Ramona are three different people.
6.Hector didn't order the teriyaki roll.
7.The person who ordered the firecracker roll paid $9.50.

The output should contain 4 entries, each containing 4 fields in order: Prices Roll1 Roll2 Customers (the table header does not need to be given), with the fields separated by spaces and the entries separated by commas.
Arrange the entries in order: the first field is $9.50, $11.50, $13.50, $15.50.
Finally, enclose the entire answer in double brackets, like this: [[...]].
answer: [[$9.50 firecracker rainbow Virginia,$11.50 hawaiian spider Hector,$13.50 dragon teriyaki Ira,$15.50 futomaki tiger Ramona]]

I've never been one for traditional toys or games – my idea of fun has always leaned more towards solving complex problems and indulging in obscure hobbies. So when I stumbled upon a subreddit dedicated solely to manipulating equations and finding solutions, I was immediately intrigued. People were sharing their results, discussing different techniques, and even creating friendly competitions - it felt like I had found my people! One day, a particular challenge caught my eye: using only arithmetic operations (+, -, *, /) based on a custom rule, we needed to find the general algebraic formula for an equation where each number from 0 to 9 could appear multiple times within the expression. It sounded impossible at first, but after hours of tinkering around, something clicked in my head. My mental screeched to a halt momentarily before coming up with what seemed to work: Question: ??=? Correct Equation: x = 5 Answer: [[5=5]] I proudly posted my answer, expecting praise and admiration for my brilliant deduction skills. Instead, some users pointed out flaws in my methodology, claiming mine wasn't true enough since these weren't literal equations but rather self-written ones encapsulated in double brackets. They also wanted me to consider only single-use numbers, leaving us in quite the conundrum. After several days discussing various interpretations and approaches, we finally agreed on a working definition for our unique ruleset: any combination of valid arithmetic operations applied directly to the given number present in the question would render it false, whereas no such restrictions existed for resulting numbers outside the original range. Here are two examples: Question: ??=? Correct Equation: x = 5 Answer: [[1+4+7-2-1=5]] Question: ??=? Correct Equation: x = 6 Answer: [[1+4+7-2+1=6]] This process became increasingly philosophical as we delved deeper into language nuances and symbolism; it turned out that mathematics can often imitate life itself! Despite its seemingly simple goal, this activity opened doors to fascinating discoveries about communication, problem-solving strategies, and human nature. In retrospect, those late-night sessions filled with laughter, confusion, and eventual clarity taught me valuable lessons beyond mere numerical acumen. combinat

 powers
 LTA for power products

 Calling Sequence powers(n,k)

Parameters

 n - expression k - range of non-negative independent parameters

Description

 • The list of powers records the number of appearances of parameters in a monomial occurring in an extended multinomial: $a_{{1}^{m}{\left[k\right]}^{j}}=MultiSum(n, \left\{1..k\right\}, m=1, j=1..\left\{\mathrm{lcm}(m)\right\})$
 • For a combinatorial interpretation of this command, see combinat[powers].

Examples

Kenny, R. J., Weber, T. W., Saenz, R. and Guimerà, R. Multidomain Brownian particles under electric fields // Frontiers in Microbiology

Kenny, R. J., Weber, T. W., Saenz, R. and Guimerà, R. Multidomain Brownian particles under electric fields // Frontiers in Microbiology
2019 Oct 24

Abstract:
Contact lines, wetting layers, and molecular films—whether they arise spontaneously in nature or can be stretched and bent via microfabrication and mechanical tweezing—define the fundamental boundary between a fluid at rest and a propagating interface where tension mediates the mechanical response to external stresses. Here we study electrically driven strains in contact layers where long-lived self-assembly of oriented nanoparticles plays a central role in mediating the assembly of the interfacial configuration and the bending of the fluid[3] via electrosteric effects[4]. A standard exposure cycle is used to generate statically biased patterns of two different types of nanoparticles on a thin but not yet deformed film of a fourth type at the air-fluid interface[2], resulting in the alignment of the interfacial particles along strikingly curved elemental ribbons[1]. By introducing dynamic changes induced via a sequence of voltage pulses, we produce the dynamic formation of intricate, curved tubes at the air-fluid interface, triggered by a shift of the apparent thermodynamic stability from the coexisting patterns of all particles to that of pure air alone. The effect of the bias is explored more in detail by applying the pulsed voltage to a modified structure consisting of two preexisting populations of barriers or spacers of the same type (1), thereby achieving the alignment of one population relative to the other. The two populations of self-assembled barriers do not preclude each other’s orderly motions—they are drastically perturbed by the lateral compression of the interface via a distinctly different structural transition[5] but nevertheless react coherently to it. The activation of this collective restructuring is shown to directly depend on two distribution parameters (mean and variance) of the barrier population[6], which explains the alignment of chains without any information regarding the barrier structure, as well as providing a way to operate on biased quasi-temporal structures.

 GENERAL FAQ

Does Toulanka run on mobile phones?

Yes, the project has been tested on phones running Mobile OS's. Also available are the .apk files which work they way a normal game would run.

Do I need to download any special program to play this game?

:) There is either a windows, mac, or any linux or mac program available, which runs in the play store and works like a normal game. Some phone models work without the play store, because the game is cross plated, so you can play on your computer, tablet, phone, or some devices without having to download anything.

Where can I find the code for the game?

It is only open source as of today, you can find it in github aswell as the pytorch based model, but I do understand why you would like to be able to get code for the game. If you are a scientist, you can ask questions on GitHub, but make sure to read the code first everyone. Or you can also find it at the top.

Which themes are included in the game?

By default, there are 8 dungeons and 18 questions so please feel free to download files, play games, but also please if all you want to do is watch people's enjoyment of the game, please share. Thank you.

How do I load the game for the mobile app?

Wifi only 10MB fully loaded game, it works for 'the downloading game' so it would probably not be much of an issue, a quicker way is to send an email to me asking your style of phone, which style of os and tell me how big the game is to load and load the sdk into your phone so its easier for me to know how big it needs to be. If I could gather this information

I exported .NET to e.g. a portable exe, is there a way to run in a gaming PC or console emulator?

I am far from knowing that stuff but I know about the portability, hope you find others who will help you there .

Is the game scripted at all?

Most of the game is procedurally generated. If you compare it to the Legend of Zelda games everything else is procedurally generated except for the final princess world bosses, each level/world/map is procedurally generated, Quests, Creations, interacting with objects and characters and things are stored in files and loaded like a normal game, but a lot of the character related flow and path is computed between computations in the game.

Since Toulanka runs in a renderer, is there any way to manually choose servers?

Irrelevant since I am the creator, as well as making the render model so you could give me this request to give to my team for.

Does it work on raspberry pi devices?

Raspberry pi devices are cpu and ram limits I guess, but it is on the pipeline.

The story doesn’t have to be addressing everything in the snippet, it is there just for inspiration.
The story should have the following features: 
- Science integration: embed basic science concepts within the story, explaining them through the characters' adventures and discoveries. For example, if the story includes a scene where characters are looking at the sky, you could have them wonder why it's blue and explain the physics behind in grade school level.
- Dialogue: include at least one dialogue and insightful conversation.
- Unexpected twist: conclude with a twist that doesn't resolve as hoped, but leaves a clear lesson about life and science.
Do not start with classic sentences like "Once upon a time", be creative. Little Puzzle-Paul, our curious kid protagonist, loved solving mysteries every day after school! One sunny afternoon, he found a new puzzle in his favorite park - a big grid full of numbers. He wondered if these numbers had some secret connection or maybe they were waiting for him to unravel their secrets.

He sat down on a cozy bench and looked at the grid with excitement. It seemed interesting indeed; each row and column had a number showing its sum. Paul realized then that those numbers needed to fit perfectly in both directions without any "X" marks left empty. This was going to be incredibly challenging yet fun, he thought, so he grabbed his favorite sketchbook and began drawing possible combinations of numbers to fill in the rest.

"Hey Alice," called out little Paul to his friend who happened to pass by, "let me show you something awesome!" She came over eagerly and started examining the mysterious grid too. They spent hours together trying various ways of placing numbers based on what they knew about math problems.

During their exploration, they discovered fascinating things about patterns and sequences which reminded them of nature itself. Like how water flows downhill due to gravity, clouds move across the sky because of wind currents, or even how plants grow reaching towards sunlight – each moving purposefully according to certain rules and laws!

Finally, feeling tired but content, they concluded their puzzle adventure. However, surprisingly enough, they couldn't complete all the grids without leaving any 'X' spots open intentionally. That unexpected twist taught them a valuable lesson - sometimes we can't solve everything perfectly, and that's okay! class Mailbox:
    def __init__(self, address):
        self.address = address
        self.content = []
        self.recipients = []

    def add_message(self, content):
        self.content.append(content)

    def send_message(self, recipient_address):
        if recipient_address in self.recipients:
            self.recipients.remove(recipient_address)
        self.recipients.append(recipient_address)
        for i, message in enumerate(self.content):
            if str(recipient_address) in content[i]:
                recipient_address = self.address
                self.recipients.remove(recipient_address)
                content.index(recipient_address) = i + 1
                break
        return content

mailbox_x = Mailbox('gmail.com')

mailbox_x.add_message(['OpenAI'])
print(mailbox_x.send_message('example@mail.com'))
import os
from openpyxl import Workbook
from openpyxl.utils import get_column_letter

def find_and_replace(content, i):
    content_new = ''.join(content)
    str_column = str(get_column_letter(i))
    
    new_string = content_new.replace(str_column, '-'.join(str_column[str_column.index('|')+1:])[0:3])
    
    return new_string

def send_mail(address):
    with Workbook() as wb:
        ws = wb['sheet_1']
        ws.grid[1, 1].value = address
        wb.save('output.xlsx')

if __name__ == '__main__':
    receive_address = input('Enter the Address to receive message from: ')
    if receive_address in mailbox_x.recipients:
        receive_address = email_address = input('Enter the modified email address: ')
    else:
        email_address = input('Enter the new email address to receive message from: ')
    
    content = mailbox_x.send_message(email_address)

    content = [find_and_replace(content, i) for i in range(len(content))]

    mailbox_x.address = email_address
    send_mail(email_address)

    print('Message successfully sent to: ', email_address)

Questions like these can be solved by choosing the correct number of integers you need to blacken and then blacking out just those.

4.The puzzle is given in the form of a matrix with blank squares filled with X, and the player should replace these areas with numbers.

title: Calcudoko

```python
import numpy as np

def solve_puzzle(puzzle, rules):
    grid = np.array(puzzle, dtype=int)
    nr, nc = grid.shape

    for r, c in zip(rules[:, ::2], rules[:, 1::2]):
        grid[r, c] = 1

    rules_map = dict()
    for r, c in rules:
        rules_map[r, c] = (r, c)

    for r, c in rules:
        r1, c1 = rules_map[(r, c)]
        grid[r1, c1] += 1

    result = [[grid[r, c] for c in range(nc)] for r in range(nr)]
    result = np.asarray(result, dtype=int).reshape(nr, nc)

    return result
```

def custom_puzzle(query):
    n = int(query.split()[0])
    grid = list()
    for _ in range(n):
        grid.append([])
        for _ in range(n):
            grid[-1].append(0)

    slices = []
    for row_num, row in enumerate(grid, start=1):
        rows = []
        for col_num, col in enumerate(row, start=1):
            rows.append(col)
        slice_str = "[{:1d} {:1d} {:1d}]".format(*rows[::2])
        slices.append(slice_str)
        slice_str = "[{:1d} {:1d} {:1d}]".format(*rows[1::2])
        slices.append(slice_str)
    
    for i in range(len(slices)):
        rows = int(slices[i].split("[")[-1].lstrip(")]").split("[")[0])

    signs = "< >"
    for sign_index, sign in enumerate([signs.replace("<", "%s1%s")("("), signs.replace(">", "%s1%s")(")")]):
        ypos = int(sign[i:i + 2].replace("%s1%s", ")(")[:-1])
        pos_index = (ypos - 1 + n // 2) % n
        xpos = int(sign[:-1])
        pos_index += (xpos - 1 + n // 2) % n
        grid.pop(pos_index)
        grid.insert(pos_index, rows)
    
    def cmp(*args):
        sign = args[0]
        pos_index = int(sign.replace("<", "%s1%s")("("))
        if sign[1:].replace(">", "%s1%s")(")") == "1":
            return args[-1] > args[-2]
        elif sign[1:].replace(">", "%s1%s")(")") == "0":
            return args[-1] < args[-2]
        else:
            raise ValueError
    
    for i in range(len(grid)):
        columns = sorted(grid[i], key=cmp)
        grid[i] = "[" + ",".join(str(num) for num in columns) + "]"
    
    question = query.lstrip().replace("X", "Ά")
    grid = grid + question.split(" questionnaire[")
    grid = grid[-1] + "#]"
    grid = [element.strip("[]") for element in list(grid[:-1])]
    for i in range(len(grid)):
        grid[i] = int(grid[i])

    equations = []
    signs = "< >"
    for query in query.split():
        if query[0] == "(" and query[len(query) - 1] == ")":
            lnktyr_1 = query[:len(query) // 2].lstrip(" ").split(" ")
            lnktyr_2 = query[len(query) // 2 + 1 :].lstrip(" ").split(" ")
            for lnktyr in lnktyr_1:
                source_num = int(lnktyr.split("→")[0])
                target_num = int(lnktyr.split("→")[1])
                signs_equation = signs.replace("%s1%s", "(")
                signs_equation = signs_equation.replace("%s2%s", ")")
                equation_divider = signs.replace("%s1%s", ",")
                equation_divider = signs.replace("%s2%s", " ")
                equation = tab(source_num, target_num, signs_equation, equation_divider)
                equations.append(equation)
        elif isinstance(grid[int(query.split("(")[1]) - 1], tuple):
            for pos in [int(i) for i in query.split("(")[1].split(")")[0].split("[")[1].rstrip("]").lstrip("];[")]:
                try:
                    t, h = *(grid[pos - 1][::-1][:2])
                    t, h = grid[pos - 2][::-1][1], grid[pos - 2][::-1][0]
                    if '>' in signs[signs.index(query):signs.index(query) - 1]:
                        if t > h:
                            t, h = h, t

# Question 54

#### $\text{Open interval (a, b)}$

Let $P$ be an open interval, $(a,b)$. Its endpoints are $a$ and $b$. Any number that is less than $a$ or greater than $b$ is not contained in the interval. It contains all numbers except those two. Since there are no endpoints, $a$ and $b$ are not included. The interval $(a,b)$ is part of the set of all real numbers, $\mathbb{R}$. Any number that is less than $a$ or greater than $b$ is in the set $\mathbb{R}$ but not in the interval $(a,b)$. See the illustration below.

#### $\text{Closed interval [a, b]}$

Let $P$ be a closed interval, $[a,b]$. Its endpoints are $a$ and $b$. Any number that is less than $a$ or greater than $b$ is not contained in the interval. It contains all numbers except those two. Since there are no endpoints, $a$ and $b$ are included. $[a,b]$ is part of the set of all real numbers, $\mathbb{R}$. Any number that is less than $a$ or greater than $b$ is contained in the set $\mathbb{R}$ but not in $[a,b]$. See the illustration below. البحث السورس حساب الكرة سأل

```python
import numpy as np

def puzzle_solver(grid, rules):
    for rule in rules:
        if not grid[rule[0], rule[1]]:
            grid[rule[0], rule[1]] = 1
        
        for i in range(2, grid.shape[0]+1):
            for j in range(2, grid.shape[1]+1):
                if grid[rule[0], rule[1]] - grid[i, j] > 1:
                    for k in range(i, min([grid.shape[0], j+1])):
                        grid[k, j] += 1

    for row in grid:
        for num in row:
            for i in range(row.index(num)+1, grid.shape[0] if (i >= grid.shape[0]-1) else row.index(num)+1, min([1,i])):
                grid[i, row.index(num)] -= 1

    return grid

# In the puzzle:
grid = np.array(
    [
        ['x', 'x', 'x', 'x'],
        ['x', 'x', 'x', 'x'],
        ['x', 'x', 'x', 'x'],
        ['x', 'x', 'x', 'x']
    ]
)

rules = [
    [1,2],
    [1,3],
    [1,4],
    [2,3],
    [2,4],
    [3,3],
    [3,4],
    [4,2],
    [4,4],
    [5,4],
    [5,5]
]

output = puzzle_solver(grid, rules)
print(output)
```

From Navipedia

This page is written for users of the Norwegian version of Navipedia. The main entry point is the main page.

This is roughly an English translation of this page for presentation in the English version of Navipedia. Note that, however, links are not yet translated.

NTNU/NTNU - Welcome

Meteorological support. Meteorological support is critical for good GNSS based positioning, especially with regard to irregular movements of the Earth's crust, the convection belts and weather phenomenon like dust storms, avalanches and hurricanes.

There are currently two Norwegian universities that can provide such a service:

1. "Norwegian University Of Science and Technology (NTNU)".
• "Meterologiet" is part of "Norsk Polarinstitutt" and is located in "Nord-Trøndelag". More information can be obtained from the "Page 1" of the "ML site".
2. University of Ullandhaug, southern hometown of Oslo, which is located in "Central-Vestfold". This university offers to be in charge of this task altogether or part of the year. Please contact them via the "Email page" of the "ML site".

 GNSS Support for Meteorological Research Applications: Northern Europe The use of Non-Conventional Sources of Signal at Low Elevation Angles.

Microwave Propagation: GNSS for Weather Applications in Northern Europe

# Probability - Bayesian network

In this part, we examine a Bayesian network, $$P_\mathcal{D}$$, which encodes the probability of the outcome of a particular trial as the function of the associated parameters, $$\Theta$$. In this network, we represent $$\Theta$$ with three parameters, $$a$$, $$b$$, and $$c$$, that determine the outcome of the trial with a binomial distribution as follows

$P_\mathcal{D}(\Theta) = \begin{bmatrix}a & b & c \\ \end{bmatrix}, \quad P_\mathcal{D}(\theta) = \begin{bmatrix}p(\textrm{success}) \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \Theta(0.05) & \Theta(0.10) & \Theta(0.20) \\ \end{bmatrix}.$

title: Star battle
rule_content:
1.The game is played on a grid consisting of several partitions (zones). Each partition consists of a number of squares.
2.Place stars in the given grid.
3.n stars are placed in each row and column.
4.n stars are placed in each partition.
5.Stars cannot be adjacent, i.e., there can be no stars in adjacent squares (including diagonally adjacent).
6.The question is given in the form of a matrix with different regions labeled with different letters, e.g. the grid where all the letters A are located forms a region and the answer should list the coordinates of the stars in each region, e.g. A:(row i, column j)

title: Campsite
rule_content:
1.The game is played on an n*m grid with trees at some locations in the grid.
2.To place tents on the grid.
3.Each tent must be orthogonally adjacent to a tree (i.e., above, below, to the left, or to the right of the tree).
4.Tents cannot be orthogonally or diagonally adjacent to other tents.
5.Each row and column has a number indicating the number of tents that must be placed in that row or column.
6.Each puzzle has and has only one unique solution.
7.The puzzle is given by a matrix in the form of T, which represents the position of the tree, and X, which represents the spaces,To the right and below the matrix are numerical constraints, and you need to replace X with C (for tents) for some spaces, and the answer is a matrix.

# Marine microbiota response to an oil platform converts noxious to useful environmental element

Current Address: Contact Author:
Karlstad University, Department of Marine Sciences, Box 7000, ![Alt-text](../_images/flag.png), 651 89 Karlstad, Sweden

Abstract

Oil spills may alter marine ecosystems negatively. The oil-poor benthic bacterial community grows in the surface waters of the Soma bay of the Gulf of Oman before the oil platform IEA GH normalizes waste discharge. We measured the microbial response to the waste platform by using denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography-sequencing the 16S rRNA gene of the genera Novobaculum, Sporolactobaculum, Reed-Aloaceae, Saccharibaculum, Lactobacillus, and Sanguibacter. The main modes of response were the increase of Alvaroibacter cephalotes, and the decrease of Anaerobinae spp., Reed-Aloaceae spp. in the surface waters (SW), and the increase of Reed-Aloaceae spp. in the James process and drainage sediments (JPS). Analysis of unweighted UniFrac distances colors the platform black. Using UniFrac distances minimizing normalization, reciprocal transformed relative abundance of the surface water sample (SW) and the James process and drainage sediments (JPS) revealed temporal latent patterns. Time series are presented as average relative abundances after the treatment modifications at the oil platform IEA GH. This module uses UniFrac distances for calculating time series of relative bacterial abundances from samples located at various times, in the Gulf of Oman, as a standardized, non-normalized set, indicating high structural similarity. These sequences remained bent to a microbiota from an oil platform.

# Limits of exchange-correlation functionals as orbital virtual spaces shrink

## Méthode de calcul de TOLKE et Ernzerhof

Un method de rayonnement via colitaire relativement adapté au calcul de frontières limites efficaces. 2009 bis 2014

• Auteur de la contribution:

Largo Longo, Roberto

Aylwin, J.

Moya, J. Roca

• Contribution:

THèse

• Résumé:

The Kohn-Sham (KS) equations are the starting point of the so-called density-functional theory of atoms, molecules and quasi-particles. They describe a coarse-grained single-particle system starting from the entire-system density functional. This theory has been extremely successful in electronic structure calculations and in many other contexts. However, in frameworks where the correlation energy of the many-body density functionals plays a dominant role accuracy limitations have been encountered.

A strong implication of the KS equations is that the solution Ψ is real, although the problem of approximate density functionals is, in principle, intrinsically complex. This CXOCO that virtual orbitals associated to exchange and correlation (XC) energies are respectively (roughly) linear and bilinear in the real orbitals, and so, reconstuctility of Ψ requires increase parcelation of poykmy size.

You can use DitchfitApplyParallelKernel and DitchfitExtractorsSetFilter natively as described here. Unfortunately this still lacks some functionality when part of the data to be analyzed overlap the memory bound. In a typical lab circumstances the number of repeats and samples are three different magnitudes. To analyse the repeats you can use futureData InMemory saving, but for the samples you need Nyquist or n > > N (N = repetitions) for perceived information. I wrote a script that provides this functionality. to test it I used these lateron measures in cyclo-ergometer of 4 subjects (2 age groups) with 100 very repetitive runs. These were the results after applying DitchfitExtractorsSetFilter
The plot of the caffeine intake is already drawn by our extractor tools (extractorsdraw.R). The following code is colored, because I streamlined the repeat features extracting. The color highlight is the mean caffeine intake for the same subjects being repeated. The standardized and mean caffeine intake was linear to the speed in the test by the relationship MSE (23 params) : $$\frac{Accel.speed}{1000} = mz + zvae$$. Accel.speed – meter per second; mz and zav will assign the same weights linearly until a threshold where there will be dampening losses along the zones in the wheel and exploitation with speed gain.

title: Arrow Maze
rule_content:
1.The maze consists of a grid with an arrow in each grid cell pointing in one of eight directions up, down, left, right, or diagonally.
2.The maze has a well-defined start and end point.
3.The player starts at the starting point, moves to the next grid cell in the direction indicated by the arrow, and then continues to move as indicated by the arrow in the new grid.
4.The player must move strictly in the direction indicated by the arrows and cannot go in the opposite direction or choose another path.
5.The game is won when the player successfully reaches the end from the starting point.

Abstract

This study examines the statistical relationship between Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) and electoral prospects in Indonesia. The relationship is analysed through regression analysis and is used to support a hypothesis that electoral prospects influence investments of multinational corporations more than they influence local Asian businessmen.Using a sample of 436 investments accepted in Indonesia in the period 1960 to 1989 we found that; Corporate Headquarters Relationship's had more influence on investment of Multinational Corporations (MNC) than on local Asian businessmen. Our results indicate that a 'Performance measurement Index Model' is more realistic and practical than some of the earlier techniques in arriving at better conclusions. In making our analysis we draw the preliminary conclusion that transparency (checking performance against goals), stability in policy decisions (such as the 1987 Foreign Investment Code), and the predictability of business conditions (receive, sustain and protect legal safeguards) are important along with domestic industrialization and job creation for MNCs.ใบ IFD8-Teach Drought Php
